segment.source: Getting started: Getting around in Visual Studio
segment.target: Getting started: Getting around in Visual Studio

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Getting around in Microsoft Visual Studio
segment.target: Getting around in Microsoft Visual Studio

segment.source: Let's now get back to the project that we created earlier, and look at how you might find your way around the Microsoft Visual Studio integrated development environment (IDE).
segment.target: Let's now get back to the project that we created earlier, and look at how you might find your way around the Microsoft Visual Studio integrated development environment (IDE).

segment.source: If you are an Xcode developer, the default view below should be familiar, with source files in the left pane, the editor (either the UI or source code) in the center pane, and controls and their properties in the right pane.
segment.target: If you are an Xcode developer, the default view below should be familiar, with source files in the left pane, the editor (either the UI or source code) in the center pane, and controls and their properties in the right pane.

segment.source: xcode development environment
segment.target: xcode development environment

segment.source: Microsoft Visual Studio looks very similar, although the default view has the controls on the left side in the Toolbox.
segment.target: Microsoft Visual Studio looks very similar, although the default view has the controls on the left side in the Toolbox.

segment.source: The source files are in the Solution Explorer on the right side, and properties are in Properties under the Solution Explorer pane, like this:
segment.target: The source files are in the Solution Explorer on the right side, and properties are in Properties under the Solution Explorer pane, like this:

segment.source: visual studio development environment
segment.target: visual studio development environment

segment.source: If this feels a little alien to you, you'll be pleased to know you can rearrange the panes in Visual Studio to place the source files on the left of the screen and the toolbox on the right.
segment.target: If this feels a little alien to you, you'll be pleased to know you can rearrange the panes in Visual Studio to place the source files on the left of the screen and the toolbox on the right.

segment.source: In fact, you can click and drag the title bar of any pane to reposition it, and Visual Studio will display a shaded box telling you where it will be docked once you release it.
segment.target: In fact, you can click and drag the title bar of any pane to reposition it, and Visual Studio will display a shaded box telling you where it will be docked once you release it.

segment.source: Many panes also have a small drawing pin icon in their title bar.
segment.target: Many panes also have a small drawing pin icon in their title bar.

segment.source: This allows you to pin the panel as-is, locking it in place.
segment.target: This allows you to pin the panel as-is, locking it in place.

segment.source: Unpin the pane, and it can be collapsed to save space: useful if your monitor is on the smaller side.
segment.target: Unpin the pane, and it can be collapsed to save space: useful if your monitor is on the smaller side.

segment.source: If you mess things up (don't worry, we've all done it), select Reset Window Layout from the Window menu to restore order.
segment.target: If you mess things up (don't worry, we've all done it), select Reset Window Layout from the Window menu to restore order.

segment.source: Adding controls, setting their properties, and responding to events
segment.target: Adding controls, setting their properties, and responding to events

segment.source: Let's now add some controls to your project.
segment.target: Let's now add some controls to your project.

segment.source: We'll then change some of their properties, and write some code to respond to one of the control's events.
segment.target: We'll then change some of their properties, and write some code to respond to one of the control's events.

segment.source: To add controls in Xcode, you open up the desired .xib file or the Storyboard and then drag and drop controls, such as aRound Rect Button or a Label, as shown below:
segment.target: To add controls in Xcode, you open up the desired .xib file or the Storyboard and then drag and drop controls, such as aRound Rect Button or a Label, as shown below:

segment.source: designing ui in xcode
segment.target: designing ui in xcode

segment.source: Let's do something similar in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Let's do something similar in Visual Studio.

segment.source: From the Toolbox, drag the Button control, and then drop it onto the MainPage.xaml file's design surface.
segment.target: From the Toolbox, drag the Button control, and then drop it onto the MainPage.xaml file's design surface.

segment.source: Do the same with the TextBlock control, so it looks like this:
segment.target: Do the same with the TextBlock control, so it looks like this:

segment.source: designing ui in visual studio
segment.target: designing ui in visual studio

segment.source: Unlike Xcode, which hides the layout and binding information inside a .xib or Storyboard file, Visual Studio encourages you to edit the XAML files used to store these details it its rich, editable, declarative, XML-like language.
segment.target: Unlike Xcode, which hides the layout and binding information inside a .xib or Storyboard file, Visual Studio encourages you to edit the XAML files used to store these details it its rich, editable, declarative, XML-like language.

segment.source: For more info about Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), see XAML overview.
segment.target: For more info about Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), see XAML overview.

segment.source: For now, know that everything displayed in the Design pane is defined in the XAML pane.
segment.target: For now, know that everything displayed in the Design pane is defined in the XAML pane.

segment.source: The XAML pane allows for fine control where necessary, and as you learn more about it, you can quickly develop user interface code manually.
segment.target: The XAML pane allows for fine control where necessary, and as you learn more about it, you can quickly develop user interface code manually.

segment.source: For now, however, let's focus on just the Design and Properties panes.
segment.target: For now, however, let's focus on just the Design and Properties panes.

segment.source: Let's change the button's details.
segment.target: Let's change the button's details.

segment.source: As you will know, to change the button's name in Xcode, you would change the value of the Title field in its properties panel.
segment.target: As you will know, to change the button's name in Xcode, you would change the value of the Title field in its properties panel.

segment.source: When using Visual Studio you do something very similar.
segment.target: When using Visual Studio you do something very similar.

segment.source: In the Design pane, tap the button to give it focus.
segment.target: In the Design pane, tap the button to give it focus.

segment.source: Then in the Properties pane, alter the Content value from "Button" to "Press Me".
segment.target: Then in the Properties pane, alter the Content value from "Button" to "Press Me".

segment.source: Next, update the name of the button control, by changing the Name value from "<No Name>" to "myButton", as shown here:
segment.target: Next, update the name of the button control, by changing the Name value from "<No Name>" to "myButton", as shown here:

segment.source: button properties window in visual studio
segment.target: button properties window in visual studio

segment.source: Now, let's write some code to change the TextBlock control's contents to "Hello, World!"
segment.target: Now, let's write some code to change the TextBlock control's contents to "Hello, World!"

segment.source: after the user taps the button.
segment.target: after the user taps the button.

segment.source: In Xcode, you would associate an event with a control by writing code and then associating that code with the control, often by control-dragging the button into the source code, like this:
segment.target: In Xcode, you would associate an event with a control by writing code and then associating that code with the control, often by control-dragging the button into the source code, like this:

segment.source: wiring a button to an event in xcode
segment.target: wiring a button to an event in xcode

segment.source: Visual Studio is similar.
segment.target: Visual Studio is similar.

segment.source: At the top right of Properties is a lightning bolt button.
segment.target: At the top right of Properties is a lightning bolt button.

segment.source: This is where the possible events associated with the selected control are listed, like this:
segment.target: This is where the possible events associated with the selected control are listed, like this:

segment.source: button events list in visual studio
segment.target: button events list in visual studio

segment.source: To add code for the button's click event, first select the button in the Design pane.
segment.target: To add code for the button's click event, first select the button in the Design pane.

segment.source: Next, click the lightning bolt button, and double-click the empty box next to the name Click.
segment.target: Next, click the lightning bolt button, and double-click the empty box next to the name Click.

segment.source: Visual Studio then adds the event "myButton\_Click" to the Click box, and then adds and displays the corresponding event handler in the MainPage.xaml.cs file, like this.
segment.target: Visual Studio then adds the event "myButton\_Click" to the Click box, and then adds and displays the corresponding event handler in the MainPage.xaml.cs file, like this.

segment.source: Let's now hook-up the TextBlock control.
segment.target: Let's now hook-up the TextBlock control.

segment.source: In Xcode, you would control-drag the button to the source code file to associate the control with its definition, like this.
segment.target: In Xcode, you would control-drag the button to the source code file to associate the control with its definition, like this.

segment.source: wiring a label to its definition in xcode
segment.target: wiring a label to its definition in xcode

segment.source: In Visual Studio, you don't need associated the control as this is always done for you.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, you don't need associated the control as this is always done for you.

segment.source: Let's change some of the properties though:
segment.target: Let's change some of the properties though:

segment.source: Tap the MainPage.xaml file tab.
segment.target: Tap the MainPage.xaml file tab.

segment.source: In the Design pane, tap the TextBlock control.
segment.target: In the Design pane, tap the TextBlock control.

segment.source: In the Properties pane, tap the wrench button to display its properties.
segment.target: In the Properties pane, tap the wrench button to display its properties.

segment.source: In the Name box, change "<No Name>" to "myLabel".
segment.target: In the Name box, change "<No Name>" to "myLabel".

segment.source: label properties window in visual studio
segment.target: label properties window in visual studio

segment.source: Let's now add some code to the button's click event.
segment.target: Let's now add some code to the button's click event.

segment.source: To do this, tap the MainPage.xaml.cs file, and add the following code to the myButton\_Click event handler.
segment.target: To do this, tap the MainPage.xaml.cs file, and add the following code to the myButton\_Click event handler.

segment.source: This is similar to what you would write in Swift:
segment.target: This is similar to what you would write in Swift:

segment.source: Finally, to run the app, select the Debug menu, and then select Start Debugging (or just press F5).
segment.target: Finally, to run the app, select the Debug menu, and then select Start Debugging (or just press F5).

segment.source: After the app starts, click the "Press Me" button, and see the label's contents change from "TextBlock" to "Hello, World!", as shown in the following figure.
segment.target: After the app starts, click the "Press Me" button, and see the label's contents change from "TextBlock" to "Hello, World!", as shown in the following figure.

segment.source: results of running the first walkthrough: hello, world!
segment.target: results of running the first walkthrough: hello, world!

segment.source: To quit the app, return to Visual Studio, tap the Debug menu, and then tap Stop Debugging (or just press SHIFT + F5).
segment.target: To quit the app, return to Visual Studio, tap the Debug menu, and then tap Stop Debugging (or just press SHIFT + F5).

segment.source: Notice that Visual Studio lets you try the app in many different devices, to check how it will perform in each.
segment.target: Notice that Visual Studio lets you try the app in many different devices, to check how it will perform in each.
